awd_titl_txt: SaTC: TTP: Small: Mobile Dynamic Privacy and Security Analysis at Scale
awd_abstract_narration:
The International Computer Science Institute (ICSI) is  developing a framework to automatically detect privacy violations in mobile applications. The project leverages prototype work in augmenting the Android operating system with instrumentation to detect when applications access sensitive user data, what they do with it, and with whom they share it. The project modifies this system to support the analysis of thousands of applications in parallel, through virtualization. This infrastructure enables better understanding of the mobile privacy landscape, as well as making available new techniques for auditing programs at scale. The project offers end-users an online resource (https://www.appcensus.mobi/) to research the privacy behaviors of their applications; regulators can use these tools for enforcement, and developers can use them to detect and fix privacy violations in their mobil applications prior to releasing them.

Current program analysis approaches either do not actually observe program execution, and instead only examine program code, or do not scale well. This approach instruments the operating system and then uses simulated user behavior via computer-generated user interface events to passively observe what personal information applications access and exfiltrate. A prototype of the framework was used to detect thousands of potential violations of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA). This project expands that initial infrastructure to enable evaluation of thousands of applications simultaneously with real user input from crowdworkers, as well as to offer a programming interface for both developers and regulators to be able to evaluate new mobile applications on demand.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop and refine our technology for automatically detecting the privacy behaviors of mobile apps in a scalable manner, and then transition that technology into practice. The technology itself allows off-the-shelf mobile apps to be run on instrumented smartphones, such that all access to sensitive data can be monitored, including identifying when that data is transmitted off of the device, and to whom it is being transmitted.

This technology overcomes several shortcomings inherent to prior approaches. For example, intercepting traffic using proxies is inherently flawed because it misses a substantial portion of traffic that uses encryption (e.g., "certificate pinning") or non-standard protocols (e.g., QUIC); static analysis yields false positives and misses dynamically-loaded code.

During the period of performance, we conducted several experiments to demonstrate the power of the underlying technology. For example, in a 2019 USENIX Security paper, we showed how this instrumentation can be combined with set logic to automatically detect previously-unknown operating system vulnerabilities that are actively being exploited (e.g., circumvention of the permissions system). This led to multiple vulnerability disclosures ("CVEs") and the USENIX Distinguished Paper Award. In addition to citing our findings in multiple enforcement actions brought by state and federal regulators, the team also received two data privacy awards from international privacy regulators for these contributions: AEPD (Spain) and CNIL (France).

We continue to use the technology to automatically detect violations of numerous privacy laws, including COPPA, CCPA, and GDPR.

In order to transition the technology to practice, we spun off "AppCensus, Inc." as a startup. AppCensus has made this technology usable by the general public by making it web based: users can test mobile apps from within the web browser, despite the instrumented testing devices being located all over the world. Data generated by AppCensus is being used by:

  • enterprise customers to monitor their own apps (e.g., HP's global privacy office is a customer);
  • watchdog groups to monitor the apps of others (e.g., both Consumer Reports and the International Digital Accountability Council were early customers);
  • Google to audit the accuracy of new Play Store privacy labels; 
  • DHS to audit the privacy guarantees of contact-tracing apps (which resulted in us identifying vulnerabilities in the Google-Apple Exposure Notification framework);
  • as well as enforcers to bring actions against violators (e.g., regulators and plaintiffs' attorneys).
